line_1: It gave some courage to our troubled thoughts,
line_2: That seeing only mark'd but half our faults.

line_1: Call for the Pity of thy Thoughts,
line_2: Thus when our Follies or our Fau'ts

line_1: Who freely judges of an Author's Thoughts,
line_2: Improves his Beauties, and corrects his Faults;

line_1: Tag Butler's rhimes to Prior's thoughts,
line_2: And chuse to mimic all their faults,

line_1: Let not their vices yet employ thy thoughts,
line_2: Laugh at their follies, ere you weep their faults:

line_1: But urge thy Pen, if thou wou'd'st move our Thoughts,
line_2: To shew us private, or the publick Faults.

line_1: He swore, the world was welcome to his thoughts:
line_2: 'Twas damn'd hypocrisy to hide one's faults;

line_1: When shall my wild distemper'd thoughts
Unguest at, unexpected, hid from Thoughts,
line_2: For no Man look'd for Blessings in our Faults.

line_1: Who cannot reach his style, or thoughts,
line_2: With ease may irritate his faults.
But lik'd the youth with all his faults;

line_1: How vain are all my Thoughts?
I know there are, to whose presumptuous Thoughts
line_2: Those Freer Beauties, ev'n in Them, seem Faults.

line_1: And with such Freedom told 'em all my Thoughts,
line_2: So often I reprov'd their slothful Faults,

line_1: But all in vain are Pray'rs, extatick Thoughts,
